This action is used in conjunction with spawn points in ARE files. The action sets the enabled state of a spawn point (specified by the object parameter).
This action causes an activated spawn point to spawn creatures, regardless of whether the time for spawning has expired. The Object should be the name of the spawn point as written in the ARE file.
Returns true only if the specifics (as set in the CRE file or by the ChangeSpecifics() action) of the specified object is equal to the 2nd parameter.

This action causes the active creature to cast the specified spell at the target object. The spell must currently be memorised by the caster, and may be interrupted while being cast. The caster must meet the level requirements of the spell.
Returns true only if the specified object cast the spell in the 2nd paramater in the last script round. If the Spell parameter is 0, then this will return true for ANY spell cast.
Returns true only if the specified object cast the specified innate spell in the last script round.
Returns true only if the specified object cast the specified innate spell in the last script round.
Returns true only if the specified object cast the specified spell on the active CRE in the last script round. If the Spell parameter is 0, then this will return true for ANY spell cast.
Returns true only if the specified object cast the specified spell on the active CRE in the last script round. If the Spell parameter is "", then this will return true for ANY spell cast.
Returns true only if the specified object cast the specified priest spell in the last script round.
Returns true only if the specified object cast the specified priest spell in the last script round.
Returns true only if the specified object cast the spell in the 2nd paramater in the last script round. If the Spell parameter is "", then this will return true for ANY spell cast.

This action causes the active creature to cast the specified spell at the target object. The spell need not be currently be memorised by the caster, and may be interrupted while being cast. The caster must meet the level requirements of the spell. The spell will not be removed from the casters memory after casting.

This action causes the active creature to cast the specified spell at the target object. The spell need not be currently be memorised by the caster, and may be interrupted while being cast. The caster must meet the level requirements of the spell. The spell will not be removed from the casters memory after casting.

This action causes the active creature to cast the specified spell at the specified point ([x.y]). The spell must currently be memorised by the caster, and may be interrupted while being cast. The caster must meet the level requirements of the spell.

This action causes the active creature to cast the specified spell at the specified point ([x.y]). The spell must currently be memorised by the caster, and may be interrupted while being cast. The caster must meet the level requirements of the spell. The spell will be removed from the casters memory.

This action causes the active creature to cast the specified spell at the specified point ([x.y]). The spell must currently be memorised by the caster, and may be interrupted while being cast. The caster must meet the level requirements of the spell. The spell will be removed from the casters memory.

This action causes the active creature to cast the specified spell at the specified point ([x.y]). The spell must currently be memorised by the caster, and may be interrupted while being cast. The caster must meet the level requirements of the spell.

This action causes the active creature to cast the specified spell at the target object. The spell must currently be memorised by the caster, and may be interrupted while being cast. The caster must meet the level requirements of the spell.
This action can be used to manually start the combat counter.
This action starts a cutscene; a cinematic sequence that removes the GUI and player control. The cutscene parameter is the script name to run.

This action starts a cutscene; a cinematic sequence that removes the GUI and player control. The cutscene parameter is the script name to run. If the second parameter is TRUE then conditions will be checked in the cutscene script.
This action starts a cutscene. Player control is removed, and scripts stop running. Note that actions already in the action list are not cleared without an explicit call to ClearAllActions.

This action instructs the active creature to start the specified dialog with the specified target. The dialog can be initiated from a distance and must have at least one state with all its top level conditions true else it will not initiate. The active creature has its dialog file permanently set to the file specified by the DialogFile parameter.
This action works the same as the counterpart dialog action without 'Interrupt' suffix. The only difference is that it is important enough to interrupt other dialogs already in action.

This action instructs the active creature to start the specified dialog with the specified target. The dialog can be initiated from a distance and must have at least one state with all its top level conditions true else it will not initiate. The active creature name will not appear as the dialog attribution.

This action instructs the active creature to initiate dialog with the target object, using its currently assigned dialog file. This action can be used from a distance and will work whether the target creature is in sight or not. Dialog will not be initiated if the creature using this action has been assigned a dialog that has all top level conditions returning false. If the target is invalid, the active creature will initiate dialog with Player1.
This action works the same as the counterpart dialog action without 'Interrupt' suffix. The only difference is that it is important enough to interrupt other dialogs already in action.

This action instructs the active creature to start the specified dialog with the specified target. The dialog can be initiated from a distance and must have at least one state with all its top level conditions true else it will not initiate. The active creature will not have its dialog file permanently set to the file specified by the DialogFile parameter. The second signature of this action is not listed in the action.ids file provided with the game. When using this signature, the third integer parameter can be used to indicate the dialog is initiated by an item (e.g. Lilarcor) - if this is the case, the item name will be used as the creature name in the feedback window.
(Does not work.)

This action instructs the active creature to start the specified dialog with the specified target. The dialog can be initiated from a distance and must have at least one state with all its top level conditions true else it will not initiate. The active creature has its dialog file permanently set to the file specified by the DialogFile parameter.
This action works the same as the counterpart dialog action without 'Interrupt' suffix. The only difference is that it is important enough to interrupt other dialogs already in action.

This action instructs the active creature to initiate dialog with the target object, using its currently assigned dialog file. This action can be used from a distance and will work whether the target creature is in sight or not. Dialog will not be initiated if the creature using this action has been assigned a dialog that has all top level conditions returning false. If the target is invalid, the active creature will initiate dialog with Player1.
This action works the same as the counterpart dialog action without 'Interrupt' suffix. The only difference is that it is important enough to interrupt other dialogs already in action.
This action is used to a play a movie (referenced by MVESND.2DA, or a MVE or WBM file).
This action starts playing a music track. The slot parameter refers to the music slots contained in the ARE header. The flags parameter indicates how the music should be played.
This action will immediately set the weather to raining, over the current overlay (rather than taking several seconds to darken the area before starting to rain).

This action starts a timer local to the active creature, using a randomly chosen value between 'MinTime' and 'MaxTime'. The timer is measured in seconds, and the timer value is not saved in save games. The timer is checked with the TimerExpired trigger.
This action starts the specified store with the specified object.
This action starts a timer local to the active creature. The timer is measured in seconds, and the timer value is not saved in save games. The timer is checked with the TimerExpired trigger.
Returns true only if the specified object is in the state specified.

If 'State' is TRUE then this action instructs all creatures in the current area(?) to ignore several states flags until the action is called with 'State' value FALSE, or until a save-game reload. The creatures still have the state flags set. This action mainly seems to be used to get player characters to look like they are "paying attention" to anything that is happening around them.

This action instructs all creatures in the current area(?) to ignore several states flags for the time specified, or until a save-game reload. The creatures still have the state flags set. This action mainly seems to be used to get player characters to look like they are "paying attention" to anything that is happening around them.
This action changes the palette (BMP file) of the specified animation object.
This action is used in conjunction with animations in ARE files. The action will start the specified animation sequence.
This action is used in conjunction with animations in ARE files. The action will start the specified animation.
This action is used in conjunction with animations in ARE files. The action will stop the specified animation.
For shopkeepers. Returns true if the specified object failed to steal from the shop in the last script round.
This action stores the current location of party members in the GAM file.
This action stores the current zoom level internally. It can be restored with RestoreZoomLevel(). The stored zoom level is not saved in saved games.
Returns true if Story Mode is active.
This action instructs the active creature to play the swing weapon animation. Note that some objects do not have this animation.
This action instructs the active creature to play the swing weapon animation once. Note that some objects do not have this animation.

The switch trigger can be used to change how the RESPONSE # sections are evaluated. Using this trigger causes the RESPONSE sections to evaluate the global specified by the 1st parameter in the scope defined by the 2nd parameter.
This action removes all items from slots of the given type from the target. The items are placed in the inventory of the active creature.
This action removes the items listed in the specified 2DA file from the party.
This action will remove the specified number of items from the party, as listed in the specified 2DA file.

This action replaces the item in second parameter with the item in first parameter. If the target does not have the item in the second parameter, the item in the first parameter will still be created in the inventory. Note that this action will not automatically equip the item that's created.
This action removes all gold from the target and stores the amount in the specified variable.

This action takes the specified amount of gold from the party. If performed by a party member, the gold is transferred to that characters gold stat (in the CRE file) and re-added to the party pot when the character re-joins the party.

This action takes a single instance of the specified item from the party (unless the item exists in a stack, in which case the entire stack is taken). Characters are checked in current party order. The item is transferred to the inventory of the active creature. If there are multiple calls to TakePartyItem() in the same block, each with the same item specified, only one call will actually remove an item (on each execution of the block). If an item is found in a container on an earlier player and in the inventory of a later player, both item instances may be removed. All slots are checked; inventory slots are checked in the following order

This action removes all instances of the specified item from the party. The items are placed in the inventory of the active creature. Items contained in containers (e.g. Bag of Holding) are not taken.
This action will remove a number of instances (specified by the Num parameter) of the specified item from the party.
This action instructs the active creature to take the specified item from the party, if they are nearby. A range for the action cannot be specified.
Returns true only if the object specified cannot be reached by normal walking by the active CRE.
This action displays a textscreen, showing text and graphics from the specified 2DA file.
Returns true only if the period of day matches the period in the 'Time' parameter (taken from TIME.IDS). Hours are offset by 30 minutes, e.g. Time(1) is true between 00:30 and 01:29.
Returns true only if the current time is greater than that specified. Hours are offset by 30 minutes, e.g. TimeGT(1) is true between 01:30 and 02:29.
Returns true only if the current time is less than that specified. Hours are offset by 30 minutes, e.g. TimeLT(1) is true between 23:30 and 00:29.
A less specific version of Time() which returns true if the period of day matches the period in the 'Time' parameter (taken from TIMEODAY.IDS).
Returns true only if the local timer with the specified ID has expired. This action does not work as a state or response trigger in dialogs.
Returns true if some type of damage was caused to the active CRE (and HP were lost) in the last script round.
This action changes the item specified by the 'OldItem' parameter into the item specified by the 'NewItem' parameter, retaining the charges/flags of OldItem.
Only for trigger regions/traps. Returns true if this trap was triggered by the object specified.

Used as a form of script communication, in conjunction with the SendTrigger() action. Seems to have the same range as GiveOrder(), and affects only one creature at once. The LastTrigger object does not get set after receiving a trigger.
This action is used in conjunction with trigger region in ARE files. The action sets the activation state a trigger region (specified by the object parameter).

Convenience syntax for NextTriggerObject(), followed by a trigger, used by WeiDU. Defines the object that the specified trigger will be evaluated in reference to. If the object cannot be found, then the trigger will evaluate to false. It will even break the OR() trigger if you don't put it in there last in the entire condition section.
(Does not work.)
Always returns true.

This action turns any undead creatures within range of the active creature. This action can be used for any creature (not just paladins/clerics) though success in turning is dependent on the Turn Undead level of the creature, which is only calculated for paladins and clerics. The chance to successfully turn undead is based on creatures level and class.
Returns true only if the active CRE was turned by the specified priest or paladin.
This action resets the fog of war for the area the active creature is in.
This action restores the docking borders, menus etc. to the sides of the screen.
This action will unlock the specified door/container.
This action unlocks the screen if it has been locked.
Only for door scripts. Returns true only if this door was unlocked by the specified object in the last script round. Appears to be broken.
Returns true only if the active creature is for exactly the specified number of ticks (1/15th seconds) left under the effect of the script action MakeUnselectable() or opcode #365.
Returns true only if the active creature is for more than the specified number of ticks (1/15th seconds) left under the effect of the script action MakeUnselectable() or opcode #365.
Returns true only if the active creature is for less than the specified number of ticks (1/15th seconds) left under the effect of the script action MakeUnselectable() or opcode #365.
Returns true only if the specified item is unusable by the active CRE.
This action is used by the engine internally. An object id is expected in the int1 parameter.
This action is used by the engine internally. An object id is expected in the int1 parameter.

This action instructs the active creature to use the specified item (object) on the specified target (target). This action is most often used to allow use of potions and wands. The item to be used must exist in the active creature's inventory (not in a container within the inventory) - though it need not be equipped.
This action instructs the active creature to use an item denoted by item at the specified point on the map. Ability denotes the charged ability to use. This action ignores the item's usability flags.
This action instructs the active creature to use an item denoted by slot at the specified point on the map. Ability denotes the charged ability to use. This action ignores the item's usability flags.

This action instructs the active creature to use the item in the specified slot on the specified target (target). This action is most often used to allow use of potions and wands. The item to be used must exist in the active creature's inventory (not in a container within the inventory) - though it need not be equipped.

This action instructs the active creature to use the item in the specified slot on the specified target (target). The ability number (i.e. extended header index) to use may be specified. This action is most often used to allow use of potions and wands. The item to be used must exist in the active creature's inventory (not in a container within the inventory) - though it need not be equipped.
This action causes a delay in script processing. The time is measured in seconds.
This action delays subsequent script actions until the voice channel of the active creature is ready to play a new sound.
This action causes a delay in script processing, randomly chosen between 'MinTime' and 'MaxTime'. The time is measured in seconds.
It is likely that it behaves like a combination of Wait() and MultiPlayerSync().
This action functions the same as Wait().
Only for trigger regions. Returns true if the specified object has walked to this trigger.
Returns true if the weapon equipped in the 'hand' defined by the 2nd parameter of the active creature can cause non-zero damage to the target object specified in the 1st parameter.
Returns true if the weapon equipped in the 'hand' defined by the 2nd parameter of the active creature can hit the target object specified in the 1st parameter.

This action changes the weather. The action only works in outdoors areas that have weather enabled in the ARE file. Values for the weather parameter are from weather.ids. Note that the fog weather type does not work in the original games.

This action puts the item specified by the Item parameter in the slot specified by the Slot parameter of the creature specified by the Object parameter in the style specified by the Equip/UnEquip parameter.
Returns true if the specified object has experience points equal to the number specified.
Returns true if the specified object has experience points greater than the number specified.
Returns true if the specified object has experience points less than the number specified.

This action can be used to set zoom to 100%. When set to TRUE zoom factor is locked at 100% and can not be changed by user input. Setting it to FALSE restores the original zoom factor. The zoom lock state is not saved.
